data.title: ESC closes terminal.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Linux 4.4.0-22-generic #40-Ubuntu SMP x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

Escape is bound to close the new terminal window feature, this is frustrating since some terminal applications use escape as a key to do certain things ( such as escape the application ).

I am now stranded in vim, with no way of getting out within my embedded terminal.

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Open a terminal.
2. Press ESC.

data.title: ~/.bash_profile not compatible?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.2.0 (1.2.0)
- OSX Version: 10.11.5

``` bash
#!/bin/bash
export GOPATH=$HOME/go
export GOBIN=$HOME/go/bin
export GOAPP=$HOME/go_appengine
export JSBIN=$HOME/node_modules/.bin/
export ANDROID=$HOME/Library/Android/sdk/platform-tools/
export PATH=$PATH:$GOBIN:$GOAPP:$JSBIN:$ANDROID
export EDITOR="code"
export VISUAL="code"
export CLICOLOR=1
function prompt {
    EXITSTATUS="$?"
    BOLD="\[\033[1m\]"
    RED="\[\033[1;31m\]"
    GREEN="\[\e[32;1m\]"
    BLUE="\[\e[34;1m\]"
    OFF="\[\033[m\]"

    PROMPT="\u@\h ${BLUE}\W${OFF}"

    if [ "${EXITSTATUS}" -eq 0 ]
    then
       PS1="${PROMPT}${BOLD}${GREEN}/${OFF} "
    else
       PS1="${PROMPT}${BOLD}${RED}/${OFF} "
    fi

    PS2="${BOLD}>${OFF} "
}
export PROMPT_COMMAND=prompt
```

It seems it does execute `.bash_profile` but it doesn't do it correctly on startup?
After doing it manually it works? (see screenshots)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/863731/15843453/9051f25a-2c62-11e6-96a2-5e5ec2e13a62.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/863731/15843499/e4fba116-2c62-11e6-83d9-2439411f7a1f.png)

data.title: Allow repositioning of the debug control panel
data.body:
On smaller screens (15" in this case), the debug control panel is hiding anything below it's top-center position. It would be great if users could drag the debug control panel across the horizontal axis (or wherever) to reveal anything hidden.

In this example I have two panes and the split editor button in the first pane is covered:

data.title: Integrated Terminal does not support font ligatures

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

First of all, having lots of fun with the integrated terminal, great addition!

I'm currently using FiraCode for my editor, with font ligatures enabled. I was able to configure the terminal to use the same font, but there's currently no option to enable ligatures for it.

Ideally we'd have `"terminal.integrated.fontLigatures"` just like we have `"editor.fontLigatures"`. Also would be nice if the terminal simply inherited the editor fonts by default (though having the option of specifying a custom font for it is nice).

Thanks in advance.

data.title: eslint.fixAllProblems introduced in vscode v1.2 not fixing all problems
Expand javascript.format options in settings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.10586

The immediate issue is spacing around anonymous generator functions but there may be other formatting options to consider with later version of ecmascript standards.

Steps to Reproduce:

Say I have:

``` javascript
var foo = function () { };
var bar = function* () {};
```

and I want them both to be:

``` javascript
var foo = function() { };
var bar = function*() {};
```

I would want to add this setting to my user and/or workspace settings:

``` json
"javascript.format.insertSpaceAfterFunctionKeywordForAnonymousFunctions": false
```

With this set, if I trigger vscode autoformatting, it only results in:

``` javascript
var foo = function() { };
var bar = function* () {};
```

*Note: The anonymous function formatted correctly but the anonymous generator function remains untouched.

I'm not sure what the desired solution here is.
Should anonymous generator functions be treated as regular anonymous functions? (my gut says no).
Should another `javascript.format` option be added? (preferred)

``` json
"javascript.format.insertSpaceAfterFunctionKeywordAndStarForAnonymousGeneratorFunctions": false,
"javascript.format.insertSpaceAfterGeneratorFunctionStarForAnonymousGeneratorFunctions": false
```

``` javascript
//  true,  true: function * ()
//  true, false: function *()
// false,  true: function* ()
// false, false: function*()
```

Another thing to consider is that in vscode v1.2 release, there is now the option to "auto-fix" eslint errors.  Could we maybe add to the auto-formatting the option to also trigger linting fixes?

``` json
"javascript.format.eslint": false, true, "beforeAutoFormat", "afterAutoFormat"
```

In which case it would autoFormat, lint, lint then autoFormat, or autoFormat then lint.

data.title: Allow integrated terminal to run as login shell
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

While testing the integrated terminal i realized that my native terminal aliases and custom commands are missing, say i have an alias like `alias ll='ls -FGlahp'` defined in my `.bash_profile` which gives me colored folder list with `/` terminated names for folders, if i try the same in the integrated terminal the output is the following, is it possible to embed the native terminal or config in the integrated one the import to the same config files of the native one?

``` sh
ll: command not found
```

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In Ubuntu just put a custom alias in the config files of your bash session, most likely `.bash_profile` or `.bashrc`.
2. Try to use that new custom alias in the VS Code integrated terminal.

data.title: Function breakpoints should have glyphs

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Currently, VSCode doesn't show any kind of graphical feedback of where function breakpoints have bound to.

Visual Studio and other IDEs show some graphical feedback to show the function breakpoint has bound to some specific locations / the debugger is in break mode at a particular line because of a function breakpoint.
It would be great for VSCode to support this in the case when debug adapters report the line(s) where the function breakpoint has been bound.

This helps users determine that
- there is a breakpoint that will be hit at some locations
- a breakpoint has been hit when stopped at a function breakpoint.

@weinand @isidorn

data.title: workbench.files.action.focusFilesExplorer can focus open editors
data.body:
This is a regression with the inclusion of stacks. I had `workbench.files.action.focusFilesExplorer` bound to <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>e</kbd> so that it would consistently focus the file explorer and stay away from working files. Now it just focuses whatever was focused last in the explorer pane (ie. same as the default keybinding `workbench.view.explorer`). 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a folder
2. Open a file
3. Click the opened file in open editors
4. Trigger `workbench.files.action.focusFilesExplorer`, the file explorer should be focused, not open editors

data.title: Pressing right arrow on an open folder in the explorer should send focus to the directories first child
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. Focus explorer
2. Move focus to a closed directory
3. Press <kbd>→</kbd> to open the dir
4. Press <kbd>→</kbd>, notice nothing happens

I expect the first child of the directory to be focused.

data.title: Provide setting to disable focusing editor when selecting a file in the explorer
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. Click a file in explorer, notice focus is sent to the editor

This is particularly bothersome when navigating the explorer with the keyboard. See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1025

data.title: Fix "Test soft idle start/stop events" test
Support Mac movement/navigation conventions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.11.5 (15F34)

It would be useful if Mac navigation conventions were supported (optionally, of course. I understand people are equally tied to the Windows conventions)

Namely:
- Page Up and Page Down scroll _without moving the cursor_
- Home and End scroll to the beginning and end of the document respectively, also without moving the cursor (as opposed to the Windows convention of moving the cursor to the beginning and end of the _line_)

data.title: VSCode crashes when opening any minified Javascript file
data.body:
I have a powerful machine with the configurations below:
Intel Core i7-4770K 3.5GHz 8MB L3 cache
16 GB RAM 2133Mhz
SSD 256 GB
MS Win 10 64-bit

If I try to open any minified Javascript file (34kb, for example), VSCode stops responding, and after ~20s it shows a dialog with the options: "Reopen", "Keep waiting" or "Close".

If I click "Keep waiting", sometimes after 40s or more it finally displays, but usually it doesn't.
If I click "Reopen", it never reopens and after more time, it shows the dialog again.
If I click "Close", VSCode is closed and I need to reopen it manually (as expected).
- VSCode Version: Last version (1.1.1)
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows 10 Home Single Language

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Download the attached [minified file](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/300771/min.txt).
2. Rename it to `min.js`
3. Open VSCode
4. Open `min.js`
